title: Worley confirms national interest concerns about Middle East suitor
text:
WorleyParsons has confirmed raising national interest concerns in fighting moves by a major shareholder headquartered in the Middle East to boost its stake and have a greater say in the running of the company.

The $8.2 billion engineering giant shed light on its efforts to stay out of the clutches of the privately-owned Dar Group after an exclusive report in The Australian Financial Review’s Street Talk column revealed it had provided the Foreign Investment Review Board (FIRB) with a document titled Worley and the National Interest.

Worley said on Wednesday that it had provided information about its operations as part of confidential FIRB processes in the context of possible creeping acquisitions by Dar.

Worley confirmed it had engaged with Dar regarding additional share acquisitions, a Dar request for board representation and for a comprehensive business cooperation agreement.

The Worley board believes that it is not in shareholders’ interests for Dar to further increase its stake by creeping acquisitions or for Worley to enter into a business cooperation agreement with the Dubai-based contractor.

“In coming to this view, the Worley board has considered the impact of these matters on stakeholders who are critical to its business, including shareholders, customers, governments, our people and partners,” Worley said.
description: Engineering giant's board says its largest shareholder should not be allowed to increase stake.
